By WARREN GULIN
After several years of neglect,
University-owned housing will
undergo extensive repairs this
summer. The past inattention,
according to Larry Denton,
Director of Student Services, was
a direct result of the University's
financial deficit.
The Alumni Memorial
Residences, Wolman Hall, and
the Bradford and Homewood
Apartments, all of which are
owned by the University, are
scheduled to be carefully
inspected and made to conform
to federal housing regulations.
Denton remarked, "There are
many strings attached to the
federal funds we use to operate
the apartments. As a result, we
are bound to comply with federal
housing standards."
Stairwells in the Homewood
Apartments which were
previously unenclosed will be
surrounded by railings this

summer in one instance of
compliance with federal housing
regulations. Richard Melt,
Director of Administration for
Arts and Sciences, revealed that
the Baltimore City Fire
Department had warned the
University several times in the
past that the unenclosed
stairwells were in direct violation

falling plaster and archaic
bathrooms will be rapaired and in
some instances replaced. Loose
bricks on the building's facades
and flawed door-jambs are also

Planned renovations and repairs of University
housing could possibly make a long recognized
deficiency of Hopkins life more pleasant next year. For
too long, the poor quality of housing facilities has been
a fact stoically accepted by students who are too
cynical to expect the University to do anything about
substandard conditions.
Also a welcome improvement is the planned
replacement of outdated and poorly functioning
kitchen equipment in the dormitory cafeteria.
Complaints about the poor quality of food there could
be diminished if it appeared that some effort was being
made to make the meals better. Valid complaints about
unappetizing food have been ignored for too long; the
complaints have become only a part of the bitter
disdain many students hold for life on the Hopkins
campus.
Perhaps, once the planned renovations and repairs
are made, students may be more willing to remain on
campus after their freshman year. If more students do
become willing to stay, then campus life will have to
become more desirable if only to accomodate the
increased number of students. The tired old complaint
about the quality of Hopkins campus life is beginning
to show signs of dying out. Hopefully, improved living
conditions on this campus can continue this trend.

in winter snow; the icicles began to run
while our children's room echoed their sleep;

while you and I silently proclaimed our love.
So that you could show the world our love,
with your bare hands, you built this house
standing high on this windy cliff's edge
at the crossroads of man's and nature's trails.
There's silence on man's roads when people sleep
but that's when nature's trails are over-run.

rippling over stony obstacles, much like our love.
We'll let love rest but we can't let it sleep
for it's a permanent resident of our warm house.

eroding sharp objects along its edge.

into blossom-filled trees ling the run

will cast a new hue in our lovely house
as nature awakes from her long sleep.
The summer nights defy the need for sleep
while lively waves lap at the sandy cliff's edge
and warm winds beat the eaves of our house,
Tanned children on these beaches always run—
Soon, they will start their own pursuit of love -not two, but four, footprints will define their trails.
And as the leaves begin to blanket our trails
and as we prepare for our long night's sleep,
we know we leave a legacy of love.
For, like drying leaves, we approach life's edge.
Ourchildren older now, begin to run
their own affairs as they leave our house.

Inside that rough-faced cement black house
we watched the birds make numb trails
in winter snow; the icicles began to run
while our children's room echoed their sleep;
The moon quietly crept over the horizon's edge
while you and I silently proclaimed our love.
So that you could show the world our love,
with your bare hands, you built this house
standing high on this windy cliff's edge
at the crossroads of man's and nature's trails.
There's silence on man's roads when people sleep
but that's when nature's trails are over-run.

Sometimes we trace the flow of water in the run
rippling over stony obstacles, much like our love.
We'll let love rest but we can't let it sleep
for it's a permanent resident of our warm house.
Much like the run's waters, it leaves its trails
eroding sharp objects along its edge.

The days grow warm as snow begins to edge
into blossom-filled trees ling the run
and violets will grow along our trails.
Then somehow the very profile of our love
will cast a new hue in our lovely house
as nature awakes from her long sleep.
The summer nights defy the need for sleep
while lively waves lap at the sandy cliff's edge
and warm winds beat the eaves of our house,
Tanned children on these beaches always run—
Soon, they will start their own pursuit of love -not two, but four, footprints will define their trails.
And as the leaves begin to blanket our trails
and as we prepare for our long night's sleep,
we know we leave a legacy of love.
For, like drying leaves, we approach life's edge.
Ourchildren older now, begin to run
their own affairs as they leave our house.
While now our trails have a less definite edge,
now, more like sleep, we have ceased to run.
Still , our love fills this warm old house.
